title: How are gravitational waves detected? - Quora

response.answer_text: The LIGO ( Laser Interferometry Gravitational-Wave Observatory ) is the best detector of gravitational waves our scientists (Kip Thorne and others) have developed. Gravitational waves causes contraction and expansion of space and this change in spatial dimension is what measured in the observatory.  Imagine a buoy floating in the ocean. When a disturbance pass by, the buoy goes up and down on the surface of the water. Gravitational waves are similar, except that the disturbance is of space-time. This mean, all dimension of space should contract, expand, contract, expand periodically. Such variations are extremely small, orders in magnitude smaller than a proton. The detectors are LIGO are capable of detecting changes in length of about 10E-18 mtrs, which should provide us satisfactory results. So, how does it work?    Image from Einstein's gravitational waves found at last - article from Nature Publishing Group : science journals, jobs, and information  It's an L shaped tube with mirrors at the two end stations. Each length of the tube is approx 4 km long. A laser light is shot towards the mirrors at both ends. A detector is situated at the corner station to capture the reflected beam. The pattern of laser light which is received is recorded continuously.  When a gravitational wave passes through, one arm of the tube is  elongated, and the perpendicular arm will be compressed. The elongation/compression of the arm will shift the mirror slightly, which is reflected in the patterns recorded by the detectors. The detector is so sensitive, that traffic at a distance of 10 km can also affect the pattern which is recorded by the detector. Thus, two such instruments are kept at two ends of the United States - one at Hanford nuclear complex in Washington and the other in Louisiana - 3000 miles away. If a pattern recorded in one place exactly matches the other, then it can be confirmed that the variation is due to disturbance of space-time by a gravitational wave.    Gravitational Wave signals recorded by the twin LIGO stations at Hanford and Luisiania. Image from Einstein's gravitational waves found at last - article from Nature Publishing Group : science journals, jobs, and information  The idea is simple, pretty much analogous to a floating buoy. The sensitivity and precision required to execute is perhaps the pinnacle of advanced technology in recent times. The discovery of gravitational waves by the LIGO team on 11th Feb 2016 marks a major achievement in our endeavour to understand our reality. It may turn out we're not that very different from a simple buoy in an infinitely vast ocean!

To spot gravitational waves directly for the first time ever, scientists had to measure a distance change 1,000 times smaller than the width of a proton. Researchers with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) announced today (Feb. 11) that they had made history's first direct detection of gravitational waves, enigmatic ripples in space-time whose existence was first predicted 100 years ago by Albert Einstein's famous theory of general relativity. The gravitational waves were generated by the merger of two medium-size black holes about 1.3 billion years ago, researchers said. These waves raced through space at the speed of light and encountered Earth, where they were picked up by LIGO's two huge detectors as a brief signal on Sept. 14, 2015. Supersensitive detectors The LIGO detectors are in Livingston, Louisiana, and Hanford, Washington. Each one consists of a giant L-shaped structure with arms 2.5 miles (4 kilometers) long. A laser beam shines down each arm from the crux of the "L," and mirrors at the ends of these arms reflect the light back.  Using laser beams, scientists have detected the physical distortions caused by passing gravitational waves. If the beams from both arms arrive back at the crux at the same time, they cancel each other out, and no signal is produced in the system's light detector. This is the normal, expected scenario. But if one of the beams arrives a bit late, a signal is produced, which could be evidence of a gravitational wave. Gravitational waves, after all, distort the fabric of space-time. A wave that passes through a LIGO detector — and "passes through" is a fairly apt description, because gravitational waves do not interact meaningfully with matter — will lengthen space-time ever so slightly along one arm of the "L," and compress it along the other arm. "Ever so slightly" does not fully capture just how minuscule this distance change is, however. The effect LIGO observed last September works out to a shift of a millionth of a millionth of a millionth of a meter — about one one-thousandth the diameter of a proton, project team members said. To put this kind of sensitivity into yet more perspective, LIGO technology is theoretically capable of measuring the distance from the sun to the nearest star — Proxima Centauri, which lies about 4.25 light-years away — "to a level of about the width of a human hair," David Reitze of the California Institute of Technology (Caltech), executive director of the LIGO Laboratory, said during a news conference today. "LIGO is the most precise measuring device ever built," Reitze added. Achieving this level of sensitivity isn't easy. For example, LIGO's laser beams travel down the detectors' arms in a near-perfect vacuum. And the system's light-reflecting mirrors hang from pendulums in a sophisticated quadruple-suspension setup, to isolate them from the everyday jiggling and jostling experienced on Earth's surface, LIGO team members said. Furthermore, the groundbreaking detection wouldn't have been possible without a significant overhaul of the LIGO detectors, which first hunted for gravitational waves between 2002 and 2010. The project then took a five-year observing hiatus, as team members redesigned and upgraded the system's instruments to get a new "Advanced LIGO" up and running. Advanced LIGO features a sensitivity 10 times that of the original incarnation, project representatives said. The new version began its first official observing campaign in September 2015 — a few days after the historic detection, which was actually made during an engineering test run. The fact that Advanced LIGO made a detection so soon after getting to work suggests that the system will spot more gravitational waves in the near future, team members said. Source: space.com

So far, they aren't.  LIGO (see Wikipedia) should be online soon.  It measures the distance between mirrors.  When a gravity wave passes, that distance changes. I like to think of it in this manner: the mirrors don't move, but the gravity wave changes the amount of space between them.  (In general relativity, gravity exhibits itself in terms of a "metric".  The metric tells you how much space is found in between two coordinates.  That distance can change, even if the coordinates don't change.)  A gravity wave is a wave of the metric; it is the metric that is waving.  This metric replaces the old concept of the gravitational field.

LIGO Detects Gravitational Waves predicted by Albert Einstein.The researchers detected the signal with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) — twin detectors carefully constructed to detect incredibly tiny vibrations from passing gravitational waves. Once the researchers obtained a gravitational signal, they converted it into audio waves and listened to the sound of two black holes spiraling together, then merging into a larger single black hole. They determined that the black holes, 30 times as massive as our sun, circled each other at close to the speed of light before fusing in a collision and giving off an enormous amount of energy equivalent to about three solar masses — according to Einstein’s equation E=mc2 — in the form of gravitational waves. LIGO is a joint project between scientists at MIT, Caltech, and many other colleges and universities. Scientists involved in the project and the analysis of the data for gravitational-wave astronomy are organised by the LIGO Scientific Collaboration which includes more than 900 scientists worldwide. LIGO is funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF)

Let me explain the process of detecting the gravitational waves (sourced from a website.): LIGO is a huge L-shaped detector that's been there since 2002, on the hope of detecting gravitational waves someday. Their is an instrument which emits a laser beam which gets split in two, and is sent down through two 2.5-mile long tubes. Their are mirrors at the end of the tunnel, which reflect this laser (the laser is shot perpendicular to the mirror). As per the law of reflection, angle of incidence = angle of reflection.  Hence, if the mirrors remain at their mean position, the laser beams should converge at the same point, right in the center (lasers travel at the same speed, and here, distance is the same).Now, we know gravitational waves warp space-time, which would rhythmically stretch and squeeze any object in it's path, which in this case, would make one tube longer and another tube shorter. Hence, the lasers would not converge right in the center, as the speed of the laser remains the same, but the distance traveled is greater in one case and lower in the other case!As they don't converge in the center, the gravitational waves are detected.

Gravitational waves are detected with the help of laser interferometers. One such establishment is the LIGO(Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory). It consists of two arms(tunnels for light) running parpendicularly to eachother and light from a single source is split and sent into each arm . At the end of each tunnel is a mirror and each beam after several reflections is sent back to the source .. detector in such a way that they cancel out each other or produce a specific interference . But when a gravitational wave approaches one of the tunnels the spacetime becomes distorted and so the light beam takes a little(unimaginably little infact) extra time to reach the detector but  this causes a difference in the interference pattern which is detected. This is how g waves were detected.
